titleStmt.title: Bedouins Harran
SHAWI Corpus

prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the teiCorpusHeader prefix are pointers to any element in the SHAWI teiCorpus document.
Private URIs using the share prefix are pointers to audio file residing on the SHAWI network share.
Private URIs using the geo prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a place element in VICAV Geodata list.
Private URIs using the zotid prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a biblStruct element in the TEI export of the VICAV Zotero Group library.

spanGrp.span: The Saudis, their current leaders and kings, are Bedouins. They aren’t Arabs! Their origin is Turkish; maybe they have Turkish roots, meaning their origin isn’t Arab. In the past, they were Bedouins in the desert.

They used to live in tents in the open desert and remained there. They had no presence in the cities. During the Ottoman era, the British helped them, so they took over instead of the Ottomans, fought against them, and became... Thus, the British gave them Saudi Arabia, and they ruled over it.

And they claimed, "We are Arabs." But they are not Arabs; they are Bedouins! A Bedouin is not an Arab. This is what all our elders and ancestors have said. They say: "They are not Arabs; they are Bedouins!"
But since they rule the country today, they say, "We are Arabs!" Meaning, they claim they are Arabs. They even named it "Saudi Arabia," calling it "Arabia."
In the past, we had a tradition of lineage. Lineage, my teacher. Let’s say I went to Syria today; there, you'll find the tribe of Bini ʕIǧil, a tribe. I went to them as a guest, as their guest.
They ask me, "Who are you from?" I tell them, I'm from Harran, "ʕIǧli." From which Bini ʕIǧil? From the specific tribe, from the Dugmān people, and they respond, "Ah! We are also Bini ʕIǧil."

"Count your ancestors so we can see if we share any common lineage." Surely, we must have common ancestors. The old ones used to do this. Today, it’s not common anymore, but I still know it. For example, I can count my ancestors.

They say, and I tell them. They ask: 'Who is your ancestor?' I say: 'My ancestor is so-and-so.' For example, 'Ḥarmūš.' Our tribe, the Bōzaw here, our ancestor is Ḥarmūš. They say: 'Ḥarmūš is our ancestor too.' Then they sit across from me and say: 'Count, let’s see.'
So that we meet at 'Ḥarmūš.' I start counting: 'Ismāʕīn al-Maḥmūd al-Bōzaw al-Maḥmūd al-ᵊMḥimmad al-Ḥasan al-Ḥarmūš.' We count seven or eight generations back, and I stop at 'Ḥarmūš.'
He also counts, let’s say: 'ᵊMḥimmad, ʕAli, son of…' He counts his ancestors until he reaches 'Ḥarmūš.' When he reaches 'Ḥarmūš,' we meet. This means we are relatives, right!"
If I don’t count or he doesn’t count, we can’t. We ask each other, and say that you, God forbid, lie, they say: 'You are not one of us!' This is the meaning of lineage. We count our ancestors.

In the past, there was no surname; only lineage existed. Everyone learned this from their family. For example, "Father, who is my grandfather? Who is my great-grandfather?" Our elders would advise the younger ones, saying, "Alright, my son, your ancestor is such-and-such man, your ancestor is such-and-such man.

When you go one day to relatives, whether in Harran or Urfa, if you count your ancestors and they count theirs, you will meet at a common ancestor. This is the matter of lineage and ancestry. This is what lineage means. May God bless you.

What is the name of your village? — This one? — Yes! — We call it "az-Zyāṛa" — "az-Zyāṛa." — "az-Zyāṛa" here is the tomb of "Ǧābir al-Anṣār," one of the Prophet's companions, peace be upon him. His tomb is here in the village.
Because his tomb is here, "az-ziyāṛa," people visit here, and they say they are visiting, so it became "ziyāṛa," "az-ziyāṛa." This is "az-ziyāṛa." — And in Turkish? — In Turkish, it is "Yardımcı."
